titlestmt.author: Prepared by Nate Scheible with the assistance of Rosa Hernandez

Finding aid encoded by Library of Congress Manuscript Division

did.head: Collection Summary

descriptivenote.p: Collection material in English with German, Russian, French, Mandarin Chinese

did.abstract: Correspondence, lecture files, writings, reviews, wire service reports, notes, book files, alphabetical files, research files, maps, prints, photographs, digital files, and other papers pertaining chiefly to Sullivan’s career as a journalist for the New York Times. Documents his years as a correspondent in China and Antarctica, and his work as a science writer and editor.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Sullivan, Walter. Assault on the unknown; the International Geophysical Year. 1961.
Sullivan, Walter. Black holes: the edge of space, the end of time. 1979.
Sullivan, Walter. Continents in motion: the new earth debate. 1974.
Sullivan, Walter. Landprints: on the magnificent American landscape. 1984.
Sullivan, Walter. Quest for a continent: the story of the Antarctic. 1957.
Sullivan, Walter. We are not alone: the search for intelligent life on other worlds. 1964.

corpname.part: American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of Walter Sullivan, science writer, were given to the Library of Congress by his children Elizabeth A. Sullivan, Catherine E. Sullivan, and Theodore L. Sullivan, in 2010.

separatedmaterial.head: Transfers
separatedmaterial.p: Items have been transferred from the Manuscript Division to other custodial divisions of the Library. Videocassettes and vinyl discs have been transferred to the Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division. Some maps have been transferred to the Geography and Maps Division. Some books have been transferred to the Rare Books and Special Collections Division. All transfers are identified in these divisions as part of the Walter Sullivan Papers.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of Walter Sullivan is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Walter Sullivan are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container or digital ID number, Walter Sullivan Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Walter Sullivan (1918-1996) span the years 1929 to 1997, with the bulk of the material dating between 1948 and 1992. The papers are organized into the following series: Personal File, Correspondence, Book Files, Newspaper and Magazine Files, Television and Radio Files, Alphabetical Files, Digital Files, and Oversize.

The collection primarily focuses on Sullivan’s work as a writer and science editor at the New York Times. The papers chronicle Sullivan’s coverage of a range of topics including space exploration, plate tectonics, black holes, expeditions to Antarctica, the search for extra-terrestrial intelligence, and the International Geophysical Year. Represented to a lesser extent are materials related to Sullivan’s activities as a lecturer and teacher, and his involvement in television, radio, and film. There is little documentation of Sullivan’s life before becoming a full time reporter at the New York Times in 1945.

The Personal File series comprises documentation of Sullivan’s life and work, mostly between 1950 and 1990. The series includes an extensive collection of Sullivan’s notebooks, expense reports, material related to his lectures, and documentation of his involvement in various professional organizations. In addition to general biographical information, the series includes draft copies of his memoirs, though most of these are available in the Digital Files series.

The Correspondence series primarily includes Sullivan’s incoming letters and is organized into chronological and subject groupings. It spans the period 1948 to 1995, with the bulk of the correspondence concentrated between 1957 and 1989 when he was most active in writing about science. The files consist mostly of professional correspondence and internal New York Times memoranda. In many cases, correspondence files exist in other series as they relate to specific projects, especially within the Book Files series.

The largest series of the collection, the Book Files comprise materials related to the books in which Sullivan was author, editor, and contributor. The bulk of the file focuses on his six major publications: Quest for a Continent: The Story of the Antarctic (1957), Assault on the Unknown; the International Geophysical Year (1961), We Are Not Alone: The Search for Intelligent Life on Other Worlds (1964; revised 1993), Continents in Motion: The New Earth Debate (1974; revised 1991), Black Holes: The Edge of Space, the End of Time (1979), and Landprints: On the Magnificent American Landscape (1984). The files primarily include research files, drafts, correspondence, and book artwork. Additional research materials related to the topics explored in the books are also filed in the Alphabetical Files series.

The Newspaper and Magazine Files series primarily comprises materials related to Sullivan’s career as a correspondent and science editor at the New York Times. These include clippings of published articles and raw copy of articles written by Sullivan for the New York Times and various magazines and journals. Most files feature topics related to science with the exception of files focusing on political issues in China, Korea, and Germany in the late 1940s and early 1950s when Sullivan was working as a foreign correspondent in those countries.

The Television and Radio Files series comprises materials related to Sullivan’s involvement and appearances on television and radio programs, mostly from the early 1960s to 1990. The bulk of the series focuses on the unproduced television program “Landprints,” based on Sullivan’s 1984 book of the same title. Additional files related to Sullivan’s television appearances between 1975 and 1990 are located in the Personal File series.

The Alphabetical Files series contains research files regarding a wide range of subjects, individuals, publications, organizations, and projects related to scientific topics featured in Sullivan's writings. The material ranges from 1929 to 1995, with the majority of the files dating between 1950 and 1990.

The Digital Files series consists of digital files stored on floppy disks and mostly includes text files created by Sullivan from the early 1980s to 1993. Memoir drafts and raw copy of articles represent the majority of the files. Also included are correspondence, estate and trustee information, and files related to the television program “Landprints.”

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in eight series:

scopecontent.p: Materials related to Sullivan’s life and work. The lecture materials form a significant portion of this series and primarily comprise notes and logistics for speaking appearances, mostly facilitated by the Keedick Lecture Bureau. Sullivan’s lecture subjects include continental drift, science in the twenty-first century, the search for extra-terrestrial intelligence, black holes, Mars, Antarctica, and in-vitro fertilization. Detailed expense reports provide a record of Sullivan’s travels and assignments while covering stories for the New York Times. The files regarding professional organizations and committees mostly document Sullivan’s involvement in the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, National Association of Science Writers, and Yale University Council. The series also contains materials related to seminars and workshops taught by Sullivan on the search for extra-terrestrial intelligence, science writing, and technology and social change. Sullivan’s experience in the Navy during World War II is detailed primarily in his draft memoirs. The notebooks contain handwritten notes related to articles, books, and other projects. However, most are undated. There is little to no documentation of Sullivan’s education or family life.
Writings, correspondence, notebooks, clippings, awards, certificates, biographical material, lecture notes, photographs, reports, schedules, itineraries.

scopecontent.p: This series comprises letters among Sullivan, colleagues, friends, and leaders in various scientific fields including Victor Frederick Weisskopf, Carl Sagan, and Arthur C. Clarke. Many relate to his professional career as an author, lecturer, and science editor and correspondent for the New York Times. Also includes letters from readers, fans, individuals seeking employment, and many unsolicited articles, essays, and opinion pieces submitted to Sullivan in his capacity as science editor. Memoranda at the New York Times document Sullivan’s role as science editor and include interactions with staff members Turner Catledge, A. M. Rosenthal, C. L. Sulzberger, and Malcolm W. Browne. Subject files contain letters and memoranda from when Sullivan was traveling or on assignment, letters from publishers, and materials related to science coverage. In keeping with the original order, incoming and outgoing letters with individual correspondents are oftentimes grouped together and filed according to the date of the most recent letter. There is no family correspondence in the collection.
Letters, memoranda, itineraries, wire reports, telegrams, cables, invitations, postcards, and various attachments.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically within a chronological file and alphabetically within a subject file

did.unittitle: Chronological file See also Digital Files, same title
Ingersoll and Brennan (literary agents), and various publishers, 1947-1964
McGraw-Hill Book Company and Macmillan London, 1974-1978

scopecontent.p: This series comprises drafts, research files, book reviews, and marketing, advertising, and promotional materials, mostly for books authored by Sullivan. Correspondence in these files includes letters from subject matter experts who edited or reviewed drafts of manuscripts, permissions for book illustrations and art, and correspondence with publishers. The most documented books are Continents in Motion and Landprints, both of which contain extensive research files. Additional research files associated with Landprints are available in the Television and Radio Files series, which includes files regarding an unproduced television program of the same name. The files related to Quest for a Continent include many of the primary sources Sullivan accumulated during his early Antarctic expeditions, including files on Operation Highjump, and correspondence with Richard Evelyn Byrd, Paul Siple, and George J. Dufek. The files for We Are Not Alone contain many research files on the origin of human life and the search for extra-terrestrial intelligence. Book files featuring Sullivan as contributor include encyclopedia entries and essays on topics including physics, the International Geophysical Year, science fiction, and science in the Soviet Union. At the top of the series is an administrative file documenting contracts, sales figures, book projects, and publisher information.
Writings, correspondence, illustrations, photographs, posters, maps, galley proofs, research files, reviews, clippings, notes, contracts.

scopecontent.p: This series comprises clippings of articles written by Sullivan, mostly from 1969 to 1981. The earliest articles mostly focus on politics, especially in relation to the Korean War, the Cold War, and the United Nations. Starting in the late 1950s, the articles begin to focus more on science, including exploration of outer space and Antarctica, then branching further into topics related to astronomy, seismology, tectonics, oceanography, and climatology. The bulk of the foreign correspondent materials relate to Sullivan’s time as a correspondent in China. They comprise alphabetical files and copy on labor, trade, land reform, and politics around the time of the People’s Republic of China revolution of 1949. The bulk of the series contains raw copy of articles with Sullivan's edits and annotations. These materials were received in bundles, mostly undated. As a result, they are grouped together in the order they appeared in the original boxes. The series also contains magazine and journal articles published in Free World, Eastern Survey, Foreign Affairs, Everybody’s, Physics Today, Arctic, and Oceans reflecting many of the same topics Sullivan explored in his books and articles. Articles from the Yale Literary Magazine include music reviews written by Sullivan in the late 1930s. Near the end of the series are lists of story ideas and proposals.
Writings, clippings, articles, subject files, notes, periodicals, obituaries.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic or material type

Chronological See also Digital Files, same title

scopecontent.p: The bulk of this series documents the development of an unproduced television program based on his book Landprints, including proposals, fund-raising efforts, grant applications, program outlines, research files, and scripts for four episodes. Other television files include broadcast scripts for Columbia Broadcasting System (CBS) news programs, the National Broadcasting Company (NBC) program “Prospects of Life on Other Planets,” and the New York University series “By the Year 2000.” Contains radio scripts for WQXR, a New York Times owned radio station and materials related to radio and television interviews, panels, and promotional appearances. This series also includes scripts for the New York Times educational cassette series “Keeping Up with the Times.”
Correspondence, proposals, writings, scripts, photographs, research files, agreements, contracts.

scopecontent.p: This series contains research files related to many of Sullivan’s projects, focusing mostly on topics related to his books and New York Times articles. The files comprise articles, maps, and other secondary source materials, oftentimes with notations by Sullivan. A large number of files focus on Antarctica, and feature such topics as the Deep Freeze expeditions, Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd, treaties, photographs, manuals, and tourism. The series also includes many government publications and photographs from New Zealand from the 1940s. The files on unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are extensive and contain many articles, reports, and rare publications. Other major topics include earthquakes, volcanoes, tectonics, planets, telescopes, radioactive waste, Alaska, cosmology, water, and Hawaii.
Research, correspondence, photographs, maps, notes, manuals, articles, pamphlets, press releases, clippings, reports, surveys, journals, newsletters.

scopecontent.p: The digital files include writings, draft copies of articles, draft correspondence, and documents related to the proposed “Landprints” television program. The bulk of the series contains Sullivan’s memoir drafts, recounting such experiences as expeditions to Antarctica, his service in the Navy during World War II, and time spent as a foreign correspondence in China, Korea, and Berlin. The series also includes files for "Terra Mobilis," a continental drift modeling program. At the time of processing many of the text file formats were inaccessible through available software. Files were most likely created on a WaveMate Bullet computer with a Control Program/Monitor (CP/M) operating system. This computer and these operating systems were popular in the late 1970s and early 1980s. As a result, these raw versions of the files do not appear as intended in their original hardware and software environments, and often include altered formatting and extraneous characters. Files can be opened with a text editor such as Notepad. Request files using the Digital ID.

arrangement.p: Arranged and described according to the series and subseries of the physical materials.
